top_comment.text:
I can tell you now, throwing in an onion, garlic, salt and pepper and 
tinned tomatoes = one hell of a bland sauce.﻿
top_comment.author: Dynasty1818

comments.text: yes :) you know what you're talking about.
comments.author: rossymilz

comments.text:
+rossymilz
If you reduce it down properly, it won't be bland at all. For me that's the 
number one reason for bland tomatoe-sauces. There's certainly no need for a 
stock pot. Just onions, garlic, olive oil, salt, sugar, some kind of 
herb(depending one what kind of sauce you make) and maybe pepper. That's 
the base. Then depending on what kind of sauce you're gonna make you can 
add other things. For a really fresh pizza even garlic, basil, salt, sugar 
and pepper is enough to make a good sauce as long as you reduce it down.
comments.author: stau ffap

comments.text:
true. add a little sugar, the tiniest splash of balsamic vinegar, good 
olive oil and fresh basil. won't be bland, and no need for stock cubes
comments.author: rossymilz

comments.text: Thanks! I now get it!
comments.author: Андрей Шарапов

comments.text:
Very simply, stock is a kind of basic soup.
Stock is a very staple additive to many recipes.
It can be used for soup, risotto, sauces, and can even be added to some 
marinades for added flavor.

If you plan on making stock, I recommend that you make ALOT of stock, 
because you can use it for soooo many different things, but if not, a 
modest pot of stock can keep you going for a while :). 

(Stock types: Beef + Chicken + Fish + Vegetable, there can be many 
varieties, even game stock, if you're interested in game meat.)
